Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in concluding applicants were neither 'Convention refugees' nor 'persons in need of protection'
Application_Facts: Applicants fled Mexico due to threats from drug traffickers and feared imprisonment for desertion
Decision_Outcome: RPD's decision was reasonable; judicial review application dismissed
Court_Ruling: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certification of questions
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of risk to life or cruel treatment upon return to Mexico
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard under subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Assessment_Factor: Time elapsed since threats, lack of ongoing interest from drug traffickers, family safety in Mexico, proportionality of punishment for desertion
Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Evidence_Used: Information on threats from drug traffickers, family safety in Mexico, duration since incidents
Legal_Provision_Cited: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Basis: Risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment upon return
Evidence_Assessed: Threats from drug traffickers, time lapse, current conditions in Mexico, desertion consequences
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Governing_Rule: Applicants must prove a risk to life or cruel treatment upon return
Harm_Assessment: Potential harm from drug traffickers and risk of imprisonment for desertion
Cause_Description: Applicants fled Mexico due to threats from drug traffickers and fear of punishment for desertion
Evidence_Handling: RPD considered and weighed evidence; Court found conclusions reasonable
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence supported RPD's conclusion that risk was not established
Decision_Rationale: Conclusions were reasonable and within acceptable range of outcomes
